isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - Circuit Function And Diagnostics - Engine Coolant Level System

svcsubproc.title: Signal Function
svcsubproc.para: The engine coolant level system monitors the level of coolant in the cooling system. The Electronic Control Module (ECM) can be programmed to shut down the engine to prevent engine damage.

svcsubproc.title: Coolant Level Sensors
svcsubproc.para: The magnetic switch sensor is used in plastic surge tanks. The magnetic switch is open when the coolant level in the tank is full.
The conductive probe sensor is used in steel surge tanks. The conductive probe is grounded when the coolant level in the tank is full.

svcsubproc.title: Fault Detection / Management
svcsubproc.para: There are no ECM diagnostics for the Engine Coolant Level system. Diagnostic Trouble Code 236 will be active when a low coolant situation is present and the Electronic Service Tool (EST) will indicate Engine Coolant Level Below Warning/Critical level. After the coolant has been restored to proper levels, Diagnostic Trouble Code 323 will remain as an inactive code and the ECM will log the engine hours of the occurrence.

figure.caption: Circuit Diagram for Engine Coolant Level Sensor

para.emph: All tests performed with coolant level full, (plastic or steel tank connector voltage checks)
Coolant Level Sensor connector (400) removed and Ignition switch ON

entry.para: Open ground circuit 34G, 11GJ or 11GS. Open in 34B

para.emph: Connector Resistance Checks (coolant level sensor connector (400) removed, measure across sensor)

entry.para: Low coolant, defective sensor or shorted sensor harness.
Low coolant, defective sensor or open sensor harness.

para.emph: ECM Chassis Connector (black) Voltage Checks (Check with breakout box installed, ignition switch ON, and sensor connected.)

entry.para: Voltage should be >4.3V w/tank full. Voltage should be <3.4V w/tank empty. (Use breakout box.)
5 Volts indicates low coolant level or open in circuit 34B.
236 = ECM has detected an open or shorted circuit on the ECL circuit.
323 = The 12V circuit at pin 10 of the ECM has been pulled to ground indicating low coolant. Check cooling system.

svcsubproc.title: Extended Description
svcsubproc.para: The Engine Coolant Level sensor is used with the optional engine warning and protection feature. The Coolant Level system monitors coolant level in the surge tank to protect the engine from damage due to operating the engine when the coolant level is low. Since this is an optional feature, the system functions by programming three way warning or three way engine shutdown in the ECM.

In either mode when the feature has been enabled and the engine is running, the ECM will cause the red Oil/Water warning light to illuminate and the warning buzzer to sound if the coolant level is below the level of the sender in the surge tank. If the system is programmed for engine shut down, the ECM will cause the engine to stop running after the coolant level has been depleted below the coolant level sensor and the preprogrammed warning time has expired. If the engine stops running in this condition, it can be restarted and run again for the warning time period, provided it is capable of restarting.

svcsubproc.title: Coolant Level Sensors
svcsubproc.para: The magnetic switch sensor is used in plastic surge tanks. The magnetic switch is open when the coolant level in the tank is full.
The conductive probe sensor is used in steel surge tanks. The conductive probe is grounded when the coolant level in the tank is full.

svcsubproc.title: Plastic Surge Tanks
svcsubproc.para: Plastic surge tanks use a floating ball with a magnet and magnetic switch. With the coolant level full, the float will raise and the magnet will pull the level switch open. This will allow for 5V to be present at pin 10 of the ECM. If the level should go low, the switch will close and pin 10 of the ECM would go to 0V. The ECM must be programmed for a plastic tank for this coolant level switch to operate properly.

svcsubproc.title: Steel Surge Tanks
svcsubproc.para: Steel surge tanks use a conductive probe that allows the probe to be grounded when the coolant level is full. This causes the voltage at pin 10 to be 0V. If the coolant level is low the probe circuit is open and a 5V signal is present at pin 10 of the ECM. If using a steel surge tank, it is necessary for the ECM to be programmed for a steel tank.

svcsubproc.title: Programming
svcsubproc.para: Coolant level monitoring is a customer programmable feature that may be programmed by the Electronic Service Tool (EST) using the customer password. The coolant level feature is operational if programmed for three way warning or three way shutdown, however, if not preprogrammed for three way shut down at the factory it will not be possible to enable the shutdown feature. Contact Technical Services or your International® dealer for programming this feature.

para.emph: Engine Coolant Level Switch Circuit Diagnostic Trouble Code

svcsubproc.para: Diagnostic Trouble Code 236 will be active when the ECM detects an in-range voltage error in the Engine Coolant Level (ECL) circuit. This condition is usually caused by a high resistance connection or intermittent short to ground in the circuit.

Diagnostic Trouble Code 323 will be active when the coolant level is low, and the EST will show COOLANT LOW. When the coolant level is corrected, Diagnostic Trouble Code 323 will change to inactive and the ECM will log the engine hours and odometer reading.

step1.para: Before troubleshooting, make sure that the batteries are fully charged. If batteries are not fully charged, voltage tests will give misleading readings. Check battery connections and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage.

Before troubleshooting a circuit, inspect connectors for pushed back, loose or damaged (spread or bent) terminals, or wires with cut strands, etc. Wires and connections must be free of damage or corrosion. When some connectors corrode, a light white residue will be present that must be removed.
Before troubleshooting, inspect suspect circuit grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage.

svcsubproc.title: Troubleshooting
svcsubproc.para: Use the EST to monitor the coolant level on the data list or to retrieve Diagnostic Trouble Codes from the Diagnostic Trouble Code list. Also prior engine events can be retrieved using the EST in the calibration data screen under the Event Log. This will display the total number of times the event has taken place, the engine hours, the odometer reading at which the last two events have taken place.
